results.lead_paragraph: MOVIES Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

results.abstract: Manohla Dargis article describes memorable scene from potential Oscar nominee The Hurt Locker; photos (L)

headline.main: The Work of War, At a Fever Pitch

results.snippet: Love is a drug, and so too is war in Kathryn Bigelow’s visceral and morally urgent “Hurt Locker.”

multimedia.caption: And the Nominees Should Be...
multimedia.credit: The critics make their Oscar choices.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: The critics make their Oscar choices.

multimedia.caption: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The Hurt Locker'
multimedia.credit: Kathryn Bigelow, the director of “The Hurt Locker,” narrates a look at the opening scene of the film.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Kathryn Bigelow, the director of “The Hurt Locker,” narrates a look at the opening scene of the film.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The Hurt Locker'

results.lead_paragraph: LOVE is a drug, and so too is war in Kathryn Bigelow's visceral and morally urgent ''Hurt Locker.'' A story about men and battle and the murderous highs of violence, the film is set in the Iraq of 2004, the year that the torture photographs from Abu Ghraib were revealed to the world, the year that four American contractors were murdered in Falluja, the year that the American military death toll reached 1,000. Written by a journalist, Mark Boal, who based the story on his experiences covering Iraq, it centers on a crew of technicians who spend their dusty days and eerie nights in and around Baghdad disarming bombs. Ms. Bigelow has spent her career bending genre to her intelligent ways. ''The Hurt Locker'' is a war movie that successfully goes where few do or can: inside the kill zone of a man's head, namely that of Staff Sgt. William James (Jeremy Renner), a young bomb tech who lives for his near-death experiences. Like most of Ms. Bigelow's most memorable characters, James has pushed against his own limits and then pushed some more. He's a danger addict who walks directly into the abyss so he can hear the thump thump thump of his own ticking heart, itself an incendiary device. But war isn't a solitary act and James can only feed his habit by imperiling others: this is his tragedy and, by extension, ours.

results.abstract: Hickoree's Hard Goods, six-month-old online shop that offers variety of necessity items, opens temporary store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn; owner Emil Corsillo, who opened shop with his brother Sandy, comments on their unique approach to pop-up retailing; photos (M)
results.snippet: AT Hickoree's Hard Goods, a six-month-old online shop with a temporary bricks-and-mortar space in Williamsburg, customers can stock up on an eclectic array of elegantly designed, no-nonsense items: canvas and leather tool bags, timeworn work boots,...
results.lead_paragraph: AT Hickoree's Hard Goods, a six-month-old online shop with a temporary bricks-and-mortar space in Williamsburg, customers can stock up on an eclectic array of elegantly designed, no-nonsense items: canvas and leather tool bags, timeworn work boots, vintage handkerchiefs and denim shirts, homemade ''tabac'' scented eau de toilette, hand-printed reproductions of 1930s W.P.A. posters, chambray ties and scarves, the perfect crew-neck sweatshirt, astronaut ice cream, Japanese toothpaste and jars of Brooklyn-made pickled goods -- essentially everything you would ever need to make it through the month of January. ''So many stores do the same thing,'' said Emil Corsillo, an artist and graphic designer who opened the shop with his brother, Sandy. (The two also design a line of industrial-looking neckwear called the Hill-side.) ''We're looking to do something different.''

results.abstract: Andrew Dawson discusses his one-man show about the Apollo II moon landing.

headline.main: Under the Radar: Five Questions About 'Space Panorama'

results.snippet: Andrew Dawson discusses his one-man show about the Apollo II moon landing.
results.lead_paragraph: In the solo show "Space Panorama," playing as part of the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater, Andrew Dawson recreates the entire Apollo 11 moon landing with nothing more than his hands, a table and Shostakovich's 10th Symphony.

results.abstract: Astronomers report that repairs done to Hubble Space Telescope last summer have allowed them to view earliest and most distant galaxies ever seen; comment about new images from telescope; most distant galaxy seen existed about 600 million years after Big Bang; photo (M)

headline.main: With Updated Hubble Telescope, Reaching Farther Back in Time

results.snippet: A new camera installed by astronauts in the summer helps set a record, recording galaxies 600 million to 800 million years after the Big Bang.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronaut repairmen had hardly finished tightening the last stubborn bolts on the Hubble Space Telescope last summer when astronomers set the controls on the refurbished telescope to the dim and distant past. The result was a new long-distance observing record. Astronomers announced in a series of papers over the fall and in a news conference last week that Hubble had recorded images of the earliest and most distant galaxies ever seen, blurry specks of light that burned brightly only 600 million to 800 million years after the Big Bang.

results.abstract: Some Haitians have turned to the Web to share information about the 7.0 magnitude earthquake that struck about 10 miles southwest of the capital of Port-au-Prince on Tuesday evening.
results.snippet: Some Haitians have turned to the Web to share information about the 7.0 magnitude earthquake that struck about 10 miles southwest of the capital of Port-au-Prince on Tuesday evening.

byline.original: By ROBERT MACKEY and NICK CORASANITI

results.lead_paragraph: Some Haitians and visitors to the country have turned to the Web to share information about the earthquake that struck about 10 miles southwest of the capital of Port-au-Prince on Tuesday evening at a magnitude of 7.0. The Lede is continuing to track online sources on Thursday to supplement reporting by our colleagues. Readers who are in Haiti or are in touch with people there are encouraged to use the comment thread below to share firsthand accounts with us, or to point to them on other Web sites.

results.abstract: Haitian Americans in Little Haiti section of Miami scan news and try again and again to reach relatives back home in aftermath of massive earthquake; churches and community centers make preliminary plans to send disaster relief but efforts are frustrated by poor communications with people back home (M)

headline.main: In Miami's Little Haiti, Lack of Word From Relatives Back Home Fuels Concern

results.snippet: Throughout Little Haiti, people scanned the news, tried again and again to reach relatives, and began efforts for disaster relief.

byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and CATHERINE SKIPP

results.lead_paragraph: Yvose Casimir slumped forward in a pew at the Notre Dame D'Haiti Roman Catholic church, her head resting on the next pew, deep in fervent and desperate prayer, while a lay leader intoned a prayer in Creole. There was not much more she could do, she said. She had been on the telephone with her sister in Port-au-Prince when the earthquake struck. ''She said, 'Oh, something's happening,' and we lost contact,'' said Ms. Casimir, 54, after the service, her eyes wild with anxiety. ''I have a bad feeling, because our family house is two stories. I have no idea if she's alive.''

headline.main: In Miami's Little Haiti, Lack of Word From Relatives Back Home Fuels Concern

results.snippet: MIAMI -- Yvose Casimir slumped forward in a pew at the Notre Dame D'Haiti Roman Catholic church, her head resting on the next pew, deep in fervent and desperate prayer, while a lay leader intoned a prayer in Creole. There was not much more she could...

byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and CATHARINE SKIPP

results.lead_paragraph: MIAMI -- Yvose Casimir slumped forward in a pew at the Notre Dame D'Haiti Roman Catholic church, her head resting on the next pew, deep in fervent and desperate prayer, while a lay leader intoned a prayer in Creole. There was not much more she could do, she said. She had been on the telephone with her sister in Port-au-Prince when the earthquake struck. ''She said, 'Oh, something's happening,' and we lost contact,'' said Ms. Casimir, 54, after the service, her eyes wild with anxiety. ''I have a bad feeling, because our family house is two stories. I have no idea if she's alive.''

headline.main: A Space Opera in a Proper Galaxy

results.snippet: With unassailable if quixotic logic, Gotham Chamber Opera’s production of “Il Mondo Della Luna” will take place at the Hayden planetarium.
results.lead_paragraph: IN 2001 Gotham Chamber Opera opened its doors at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side of Manhattan with what was billed as the American stage premiere of the teenage Mozart's moral allegory ''Il Sogno di Scipione,'' set in the Temple of Heaven. Now, after nine years spent establishing a repertory of rarities from Monteverdi to Piazzolla, the company is preparing its next space adventure. The vehicle this time is Haydn's comedy ''Il Mondo Della Luna'' (''The World on the Moon''), to be presented, with unassailable if quixotic logic, in the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History beginning on Tuesday evening. As you may expect, the world on the moon is a place in a patsy's mind. The gullible Gulliver who gets taken there is the elderly Buonafede, who starts out with buckets of money, two marriageable daughters to tyrannize and a mercenary maid who wraps him around her little finger. He also has a personal astronomer, Ecclitico, through whose spyglass he glimpses titillating lunar shenanigans. (A young woman pleasures an old man; a husband canes his wife; an abused mistress pleads with her lover for mercy.) Deposited back on earth in the third act, Buonafede has only his memories of his fake adventure. The youngsters have made matches to suit themselves, siphoning off generous dowries besides. Yet with little ado, Buonafede comes round, and for the moment all's right with the world.

results.abstract: No, little green men haven't found Twitter-but astronauts aboard the International Space Station have.
results.snippet: No, little green men haven't found Twitter-but astronauts aboard the International Space Station have.
results.lead_paragraph: On Friday Timothy Creamer, an Astronaut on board the International Space Station (I.S.S.), sent the first live tweet from space. It was one small tweet for man, one giant tweet for mankind.

headline.main: Let's Build a Stairway to Mars

results.snippet: It's time to turn astronauts into true explorers again, with Mars as the goal.
results.lead_paragraph: Human space flight is at a tipping point. Next September, after 29 years of flights, the Space Shuttle is scheduled to be launched for the last time. The future of U.S. crewed missions is currently being reviewed at the highest levels of the Obama administration, with a decision expected early next month. This follows the delivery in October of a rather bleak reassessment of the activity by an expert commission led by Norman Augustine, the former Lockheed Martin CEO. Its verdict was that without an increase in funding, U.S. crewed space flight ''appears to be on an unsustainable trajectory.''

results.abstract: Mike Hale reviews new CBS reality series Live for the Moment, hosted by Jeff Probst; photo (M)

headline.main: Quest for Joy and Wonder Before Time Runs Out

results.snippet: CBS’s “Live for the Moment” is the latest spin on the bucket-list idea. The twist is that unlike with other, similar projects, the person checking off things to do before he dies is actually dying.
results.lead_paragraph: The cues for tenderness and uplift are all over ''Live for the Moment'': the choked-back tears, the crowds of applauding family and friends, the corny speeches, the constant reiterations (essential for this sort of reality show) of how amazing the whole experience has been. Those of us who find it slightly depressing and more than a little creepy are probably outside the target audience to begin with. This brainchild of Mark Burnett and Jeff Probst, the executive producer and host of ''Survivor,'' is the latest spin on the bucket-list idea. The twist is that the person checking off things to do before he dies isn't fictional (as in the film ''The Bucket List'') or young and healthy (as in the MTV series ''The Buried Life''). He's actually dying.

results.abstract: Administration officials say Pres Obama will end NASA's return mission to moon and turn to private companies to launch astronauts into space when he unveils his budget request to Congress; changes have angered some Congress members, particularly from Texas, location of Johnson Space Center, and Florida, location of Kennedy Space Center; photo (M)
results.snippet: The changes have angered some members of Congress, particularly in Texas and Florida where the Johnson and Kennedy Space Centers are located.
results.lead_paragraph: President Obama will end NASA's return mission to the moon and turn to private companies to launch astronauts into space when he unveils his budget request to Congress next week, an administration official said Thursday. The shift would ''put NASA on a more sustainable and ambitious path to the future,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the changes have angered some members of Congress, particularly from Texas, the location of the Johnson Space Center, and Florida, the location of the Kennedy Space Center.
